message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a mass in the anterior neck area, undetectable TSH, thyroid-receptor antibodies, and diffusely increased iodine uptake indicate a diagnosis of Graves disease. L-thyroxine therapy is a long-term treatment option for this condition. Near-total thyroidectomy may be considered in certain cases, but it is not the first line of treatment. Methimazole therapy and propranolol therapy may be used in the short term to manage symptoms, but L-thyroxine therapy is the long-term treatment.

Treatment with radioactive iodine is often used for this condition, which will ultimately result in hypothyroidism, for which long-term treatment with L-thyroxine is needed. Near-total thyroidectomy and methimazole therapy are other treatment options for hyperthyroidism, but they are less commonly used than radioactive iodine therapy. Propranolol therapy can be used for symptom control, but it does not address the underlying thyroid dysfunction.
